content.title: Aortic Dissection Classification Systems
content.summary: Multiple classification systems exist for aortic dissection, each with different focuses. The Stanford and DeBakey systems classify by anatomical extent, while newer systems incorporate timing, complications, and imaging characteristics.
content.definition: Systematic categorization of aortic dissections based on anatomical involvement, timing, complications, and other factors to guide treatment decisions and prognostication

stanford_classification.description: Based on involvement of ascending aorta, regardless of entry site

type_A.definition: Any dissection involving the ascending aorta
type_A.includes: Arch and descending involvement if ascending involved

type_B.definition: Dissection NOT involving the ascending aorta

debakey_classification.description: Based on entry site and extent of propagation

type_I.definition: Entry in ascending, propagates to at least aortic arch (often descending)

type_II.definition: Entry and propagation limited to ascending aorta only

chronic.significance: Aortic wall remodeled; different management considerations

penn_classification.description: Stratifies Type A by ischemia and circulatory status
penn_classification.class_Aa: No branch vessel malperfusion, no circulatory instability
penn_classification.class_Ab: Branch vessel malperfusion without circulatory instability
penn_classification.class_Ac: Circulatory instability (tamponade, AI) without branch malperfusion
penn_classification.class_Abc: Both branch malperfusion and circulatory instability

TEM_classification.based_on: Entry tear location and distal extent

dissection_vs_variants.intramural_hematoma: No identifiable intimal tear or flow in false lumen

clinical_application.stanford: Most commonly used for initial treatment decisions
clinical_application.debakey: Provides more anatomic detail for surgical planning
clinical_application.penn: Refines Type A prognosis and prioritization

definition.@value: Systems for categorizing aortic dissections by anatomy, timing, and complications

medicalCode.description: Dissection of unspecified site of aorta

learning_objectives: Apply Stanford classification to determine treatment urgency
Distinguish DeBakey types and their anatomical features
Define timing categories and their clinical significance
Describe the Penn classification for Type A stratification
Differentiate classic dissection from other acute aortic syndromes
clinical_pearls: Stanford A = involves ascending = emergent surgery
Stanford B = does NOT involve ascending = medical unless complicated
Acute = <14 days; Subacute = 14-90 days; Chronic = >90 days
DeBakey I/II = Stanford A; DeBakey III = Stanford B
Penn class Abc (both malperfusion AND instability) has worst prognosis
